passage_list.text: I spent that first afternoon alone, without my family, on the terrace of the Café Ti-Loup, in a pleasant state of half-reading, half-listening to a couple arguing, to a father and his adolescent son sharing a moment of taut silence, glad for once not to be contributing to the ambient family discord but bearing peaceable witness to it instead. I was getting ready to leave my table when I saw her, walking on the other side of the street, and into the caisse populaire. The similarity was so uncanny that it wouldn’t be right to merely call it a resemblance. No, in that instant, there was no doubt in my mind that it was her, my mother, as she had been the year of her death, nearly twelve years before—tall, fair, the same proud, inquisitive nose, the dark, expressive parentheses for eyebrows. I drank three large gulps of water, standing there above the flimsy outdoor table, trying to steady my hands, which were now cold and shaking, the nails drained of their pink. My mind immediately set to breaking the spell: the hair was different and I didn’t remember my mother being quite so tall. And yet I could not convince myself that it was not her. The waitress asked me if I needed anything, she was hoping to give the table to someone else, and I managed to say absentmindedly: Non, tout va bien, mademoiselle, allez-y, and step out onto the sidewalk, where I stood, agitated, like a dog tied to a lamppost, waiting for its owner to return from an errand.

Moments later, my mother emerged from the bank again, her head down, as she placed a large wallet, with its old-fashioned ball clasp, the very kind I suddenly remembered she’d always carried, back into her handbag. As she lifted her head my error was revealed: the nose was all wrong—flatter, broader—the eyebrows thicker and far darker than I’d first thought. The entire effect was unpleasant, and I was reminded of the time when in a restaurant some years earlier on Saint-Denis, out for dinner with my husband, Bertrand, I had ordered a cheese soufflé and found, past the miraculous and airy dome, the slimy amniotic soup of raw egg beneath.

That queasy feeling, a tightness at my jaw, remained all day. By the evening, even the apartment had begun to bear the signs of my nausea, of this close call with another realm. I opened the door to my daughter’s room and turned the lights on and off and back on again. What did I hope to find there? My mother, smiling, her teeth in their gentle disarray, her heavy breasts, her unyielding blue eyes? In reality, I found nothing but the indelible traces of my daughter—opposite to my mother’s old-world austerity—the bright colors of the feather boa that she had worn at Halloween slung over the headboard. Dafna was a girl of accessories, talismans, shells collected and arranged, collages she’d made tacked to the corkboard, memories of herself.

I had collected nothing as a child, not a rock or a doll.

We had spent the days before Dafna’s departure for summer camp shopping and packing, finding the perfect sleeping bag and flip-flops, the myriad toiletries that pleased her. Under regular circumstances, I would have let Bertrand take care of this part of the preparations, but I must have felt a certain amount of guilt about the plan from which I had excluded myself entirely. He would drive her to the camp just north of Quebec City; he would pick her up. And in the interim, he would take the opportunity to visit with his mother, who had been recently widowed and was desperate for the company of her favorite child. There had been some talk, when the plan had first been devised, of my going with them, staying with Bertrand in his mother’s house, but the accommodation was uncomfortable, a lone cot that we would have to share like much younger versions of ourselves. In those first years together, I had welcomed the discomfort of this sleeping arrangement and its forced physical closeness verging on siblinghood, which, having grown up as an only child, I found nearly erotic. Or perhaps, to put it simply, I had been hungry, in those early years, for any excuse to be physically close to Bertrand. His nearness, from the beginning, had seemed like a kind of concession granted to me by some stroke of luck or circumstance.

His mother, it was no great secret, had never especially liked me. She had couched the feeling as linguistic in nature, cultural in kind. My French, at age twenty, had been so halting and internal, I could not blame her for finding me an odd and abrupt successor to Bertrand’s most recent girlfriend, a francophone classmate in his PhD program, whom he had been with for the better part of a decade. But it was my refusal, a few years later, to christen our daughter, which I justified would have ostracized me permanently from my own Jewish family, that had been my first unpardonable sin. My open insistence on speaking English to Dafna, even when we visited Quebec City, had surely not helped my cause either. But even after it had been clear that my efforts had failed—Dafna had not spoken a word to me in English since she had started public school in French two years earlier, and there were increasingly vociferous stirrings about wanting to be confirmed—Bertrand’s mother’s disapproval had broadened, like a kind of generosity, to include the farthest reaches of my decision-making: my choice to work only part-time as a homework assistant in an English boys’ school, my preference not to dye my hair, even after it turned, shortly after Dafna’s birth, prematurely salt and pepper.

I would not have said, at the time, that summer of 1992, that my family was falling apart, only that we were at something like an impasse, that it was true that my eight-year-old daughter’s sizable will had recently flourished and seemed aimed at annihilating me. My husband, despite his efforts at fairness, firmly sided with our daughter, and so a fault line had emerged, and I had found it easy to simply give myself over to it, to fall into this trench in my own family life. And yet the problem was that I could not remember a time before this one, the arrangement before this one. I could not recall ever having been pleasantly and easily at the center of my own life, at the center of Bertrand’s attentions. Like all small familial tragedies, it seemed, that year, as though it had been there all along, this truth, waiting to live out its inevitability. For months now, I had wanted this time alone, advocated for it. In our ten years together, I had asked for almost nothing from Bertrand. This is not to say that I had been a particularly good wife, only that my badness, if you could call it that, had little to do with making actual demands.

questions.question: What best describes the narrator's state of mind as she spends the afternoon on the terrace?
questions.explanation: The narrator describes herself in a 'pleasant state of half-reading, half-listening,' suggesting she is reflective and observant, taking in the surroundings with a calm attentiveness.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on adjectives and descriptive phrases to understand the tone and mood set by the author.

questions.question: Which detail most effectively reveals the narrator’s internal conflict about recognizing the figure she sees?

options.A: Her hands were cold and shaking as she drank water.
options.B: She immediately noted that her mother's hair was different and questioned her height.
options.C: She compared the current moment to the peaceful ambience of the café.
options.D: She casually responded to the waitress before stepping out onto the sidewalk.

questions.explanation: The narrator’s focus on the differences—such as her mother's hair and stature—directly highlights her internal struggle between recognizing a familiar face and doubting the memory.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for specific textual details that indicate internal conflict, rather than general descriptions of physical actions.

questions.question: In the passage, the phrase "the slimy amniotic soup of raw egg" is used primarily to:

options.A: Literally describe the texture of a cheese soufflé.
options.C: Employ hyperbolic imagery to evoke disgust at an unexpected interior.
options.D: Introduce an unrelated memory about dining out.

questions.explanation: The vivid and exaggerated description serves as a hyperbolic image that emphasizes the narrator's repulsion and surprise upon discovering an unpleasant detail in what was expected to be a light, airy dish.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to unusual imagery; such descriptions often carry deeper emotional or critical weight in the text.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the narrator's feelings when she enters her daughter's room?

options.A: She is indifferent to the changes in her family.
options.B: She is searching for a connection to her past, particularly to her mother.
options.C: She is solely focused on her daughter’s personal belongings.
options.D: She is relieved to be away from troubling memories.

questions.explanation: The narrator’s momentary hope to find her mother’s features in her daughter's room suggests she is longing for a connection to her past and the presence of her mother.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Infer emotional undercurrents by considering both what the narrator explicitly states and what she hopes to find.

questions.question: How does the transition from the narrator’s description of her queasy feeling to the details in her daughter's room function in the passage?

options.A: It highlights the contrast between internal distress and external reality.
options.B: It underscores the continuity of her mother's influence.
options.C: It signals a shift from past memories to present actions.
options.D: It indicates her growing detachment from familial history.

questions.explanation: The shift from describing her physical unease to the tangible evidence in her daughter’s room accentuates the dissonance between her internal emotional state and the external environment.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Examine how transitions in a passage connect internal emotions with external details to deepen thematic understanding.

questions.question: Which detail best reveals the narrator’s reflection on her own childhood?

options.A: Her recollection of not having collected anything as a child.
options.B: The description of the summer camp preparations.
options.C: Her guilt over excluding herself from the planning process.
options.D: Her longing for the physical closeness she once experienced with Bertrand.

questions.explanation: The simple statement about not having collected anything as a child poignantly underscores a feeling of emptiness or disconnection from her past.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify brief, reflective statements that encapsulate broader themes about identity and memory.

questions.question: In what way does the discussion of summer camp preparations contribute to the overall narrative?

options.A: It underscores the narrator's growing independence.
options.B: It highlights the complexities of familial roles and expectations.
options.C: It introduces humor to offset the narrative's tension.
options.D: It serves as a mere background detail without thematic significance.

questions.explanation: The detailed account of preparing for summer camp reveals underlying tensions and expectations within the family, particularly regarding roles and responsibilities.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Consider how narrative details, even those that seem mundane, can reflect deeper family dynamics and character relationships.

questions.question: Which sentence best demonstrates correct parallel structure?

options.A: "She had couched the feeling as linguistic in nature, cultural in kind."
options.B: "My French, at age twenty, had been so halting and internal, I could not blame her."
options.C: "Dafna had not spoken a word to me in English since she had started public school, and there were stirrings about wanting to be confirmed."
options.D: "I would not have said that summer of 1992 that my family was falling apart, only that we were at an impasse."

questions.explanation: The sentence uses a balanced structure with two adjectives—"linguistic in nature, cultural in kind"—which creates a clear parallelism.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Review sentences for balanced grammatical elements, particularly in paired descriptions or lists.

questions.question: What central theme emerges in the final portion of the text?

options.B: The longing for past familial connections
options.C: The challenges of adapting to cultural expectations
options.D: The tension between personal identity and familial obligations

questions.explanation: The final portion of the passage highlights the conflict between the narrator's personal choices and the weight of familial expectations, emphasizing the tension in her identity.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the underlying conflict or tension in the narrative to determine its central theme.

questions.question: How does the narrator synthesize her personal history with her current experiences to comment on family dynamics?

options.A: By contrasting her solitary past with her current family obligations.
options.B: By linking physical descriptions of family members to their emotional states.
options.C: By recounting unrelated memories that suggest family dysfunction.
options.D: By using vivid imagery and reflective narrative to illustrate the evolution of familial relationships over time.

questions.explanation: The narrator weaves together past memories and current observations through vivid imagery and reflective commentary, providing a nuanced perspective on how family dynamics transform over time.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for how the author connects disparate elements of the narrative to form a cohesive commentary on broader themes.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and the ability to make nuanced inferences based on textual details.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with the more complex analytical questions that require deeper synthesis of ideas.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer deeper meanings, analyze complex structures, and understand nuanced word choices.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and the ability to locate and apply textual evidence, as well as understanding vocabulary in context.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit details and central ideas in the text.
